result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Adrian Toga Velasco

records.addlTxt: Motion hearing on November 7, 2022 at 03:45 pm.

Clerk: Amy. 
Called:  2:53 p.m. 
State appears by ADA Kyle Mayo. 
Atty John Mathie appears on behalf of defendant. 
Defendant fails to appear. 
Spanish interpreter, Laura Salcido appears by video (Court excuses). 

Date and time set for motion hearing.  
Atty Mathie has no information re: deft's non-appearance and makes statement; requests warrant not be issued. 
COURT notes proper notice was sent for today. 
ADA Mayo requests warrant be issues with bond forfeiture. 

COURT gives last chance for defendant to appear at next hearing. 

COURT directs Atty Mathie to set a date with Judicial Assistant and advises defendant must appear. 

Adj:  2:55 p.m.

RECALLED:  2:56 p.m. 
Defendant now appears with Atty Mathie. 
COURT has already excused interpreter however warns defendant to appear on time for next hearing. 

Adj:  2:56 p.m.
Defendant's NMM to Compel Disclosure
Regarding Release of Controlled Buy Video
